Why Computer Science Is Important: Insights from Reza Peyrovian

Mastering Computer Science
Stevens Online
November 10, 20219 min read

We sat down with Peyrovian to find out what distinguishes computer science among academic disciplines and what distinguishes the StevensOnline master‚Äôs program in computer science from its competitors. Below, he discusses computer science from the dual perspectives of a seasoned industry professional and an accomplished academic.

WHY COMPUTER SCIENCE IS IMPORTANT?

Computer science solves problems. Let me offer an example from my career. I worked at Bell Labs for 25 years. The first project I led developed a processor from scratch. It took four to five years to complete the project. I had to learn the nuts and bolts, from the properties of silicon all the way to the logic of creating a processor that‚Äôs fault-tolerant and real-time and meets the requirement of no more than three minutes of downtime per year. How do you create the hardware and software to do that? These are the kinds of problems you can solve as a computer scientist. In the end, it cost Bell Labs $1.8 billion to develop and deploy that processor. It‚Äôs still running in the AT&T network, many years later.

INDUSTRY LEADERS LEAD OUR CLASSROOMS

A WORLD CLASS EDUCATION BASED ON REAL WORLD EXPERIENCE

Later, I moved into software development. I developed software for mobile systems and provisioning systems. At that point, I started to miss teaching ‚Äî I am an educator. Friends told me there was a great opportunity at Stevens, so I joined. At this point, I‚Äôve taught most of the courses in the program.

YOU‚ÄôVE BEEN TEACHING ONLINE FOR YEARS. HOW HAS ONLINE COMPUTER SCIENCE INSTRUCTION CHANGED?

Years ago, we used to post content online and students would go read it. We didn‚Äôt really interact with students that much unless they came to office hours. But it‚Äôs evolved, and now there‚Äôs quite a bit of facetime ‚Äî an hour and a half each week in each course. Teleconferencing apps make that possible. To me, there‚Äôs no difference between sitting in a live classroom and sitting on Zoom. I get to know students, I answer their questions in class and in meetings. Students are involved in a very interactive way even though they are not physically sitting in front of us.

Breakout rooms make it easy for them to collaborate and then share their group‚Äôs solution to a problem or ask questions. I usually pose a problem and then talk about it, and then students go into breakout rooms of three to five people and develop the answer together. We then discuss the solution from two or three of the breakout groups, which I choose at random. It makes the session much more lively than it would be if I just stood in front of the class and showed graphs and lectured.

As we understand online learning better, we‚Äôve developed content designed to work in an online format. We try to do as much interactive content as possible, and online textbooks are becoming more interactive as well. It‚Äôs not just reading and memorizing. It‚Äôs practice. The textbooks include participation activities, in which students answer questions as they read. It reinforces what they learn and it‚Äôs low stakes; you keep answering until you get the correct answer. Then there are challenge activities, in which students get graded on whether they answer correctly. Students like this format, and we‚Äôve found it‚Äôs very effective in preparing them for the live sessions.

TELL ME MORE ABOUT THE FORMAT OF THE ONLINE MSCS PROGRAM.

When possible, we use videos to teach concepts. In my algorithms class, for example, we‚Äôve created a series of original, professionally produced videos teaching about algorithms inspired by nature. Whether it‚Äôs from ants or a cuckoo bird, nature can teach us how to solve some algorithm problems. Students get a new perspective. They see it‚Äôs not just stacks and queues.

One set of videos approaches the elevator algorithm from different angles. Students have to figure out: What are we trying to optimize? Are we trying to save energy? Get people to the floor they want to get to as fast as possible? Should it be first-come, first-served, or should we factor in the direction of the elevator? It‚Äôs a complex problem. You have to look at the pattern of movement of people, not just who is going where but how many people are waiting on each floor, and at what time. In the morning, there‚Äôs a lot of traffic from the lobby to offices. At noon, there‚Äôs a lot of traffic to and from the cafeteria. The algorithm has to become a learning machine, so now this lesson in algorithms also becomes a lesson in the importance of machine learning and artificial intelligence. It turns out this problem is NP-complete, so it‚Äôs not solvable in the way we might want to solve it. But we can solve it by learning from ants, looking at how they find food and bring it to their nest ‚Äî which brings us back to learning from nature. The videos teach all this, tie it all together in an engaging and memorable way.

We tackle a lot of interesting problems in algorithms: how to match medical students to medical schools to optimize for both students and schools, how to create mazes, how to connect people on social networks.

We are in a new era. We used to try to solve problems for computers, but we‚Äôre past that. Modern computers are fast; we don‚Äôt need to worry about optimizing them further. People keep talking about big O notation, and yes, it‚Äôs important to make things more efficient, but the big goal of algorithms is to make our lives easier ‚Äî problem-solving for human satisfaction. People sometimes worry that computers will take over, but they don‚Äôt need to be afraid of that. If we program them the way we want, they will do the things we want.

CAN STUDENTS CUSTOMIZE THE PROGRAM?

We decided to run the program on a cohort model, which means everyone takes the same computer science courses at the same time as the group they came in with. It‚Äôs important that students go through this experience together. They interact and get to know each other well, and the lockstep curriculum ensures that students have the necessary background to understand each course in the sequence.

The program does vary a bit depending on whether you come in with a computer science background. A lot of students in this program don‚Äôt have a computer science background. If you didn‚Äôt get a computer science education as an undergraduate, you need to take some remedial catch-up courses. Our program includes two that you take at the outset of the program, followed by eight fundamental foundational courses. Students who come in with a computer science background don‚Äôt have to do those two courses. We have two other courses for them instead: one on agile processes and one on human-computer interaction.

This program is designed to cover all the areas that industry wants, all the hot subjects in computer science. We cover all kinds of computer programming: cloud programming, software development, mobile systems, web programming. Plus, we provide the foundation you need to keep learning on your own after you earn the degree.

A PROSPECTIVE STUDENT ASKS, ‚ÄúI‚ÄôM THINKING ABOUT A MASTER‚ÄôS, BUT ALTERNATIVELY I‚ÄôM THINKING ABOUT DOING A CERTIFICATE OR A BOOT CAMP. WHY SHOULD I GET A MASTER‚ÄôS?‚Äù

Getting a certificate and learning one narrow area is one way of picking up on a subject. Alternatively, you can also train yourself so that you can learn anything in the future on your own. Then, you won‚Äôt need to keep going back to get more certificates. You‚Äôll have a good foundation on which to learn other topics on your own or in practice. Education gives you that foundation, the ability to learn.

What you learn in a certificate program can be pretty superficial. You study, you pass an exam ‚Äî you don‚Äôt have to go deep. In earning a master‚Äôs-level computer science degree, you spend four or five courses learning fundamentals that have remained the same since the inception of the computer. Take computer architecture. You have to know it. Once you do, you don‚Äôt expect the machine to do the impossible. You know what it can do, what it can‚Äôt do, that it‚Äôs not a magic box. I teach students what a tortuous process the computer takes to add two numbers. When you learn that, you know what computers can do and cannot do in terms of network, parallelism, and creating a distributed system. You learn all of that so you can use them properly.

WHY SHOULD MASTER‚ÄôS STUDENTS STUDY COMPUTER SCIENCE ONLINE AT STEVENS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY?

Stevens is an institution built on a foundation of engineering, software, and computer science. We have some of the best faculty members in the computer science department. The bar is set very high for content.

AN IN DEMAND DEGREE FOR IN DEMAND JOBS

GIVE YOURSELF A PROFESSIONAL ADVANTAGE WITH A MASTER‚ÄôS

Students here learn the fundamentals as well as today‚Äôs hot areas, like how to develop cloud service and how to do application programming for distributed systems, not just client server-side applications. We cover data structure, algorithms, and the nuts and bolts of the machine. We cover computer organization and design to really understand how computers work, even how GPUs work. Students learn agile processes for software development. When they leave here and enter a work environment, they will be able to be productive. From the time they enter, they can join the teams and work on those processes, or become a web programmer or mobile systems applications programmer.

Finally, we produce results: our computer science graduates quickly find jobs in the Northeast. In the summertime, I have difficulty getting teaching assistants because they all get high-paying internships that provide valuable professional experience to help them along their career path.

At Stevens, you‚Äôll learn from National Science Foundation CAREER winners, top researchers and industry consultants, and experts in computer science subfields like machine learning and AI. Thanks to the online format, you‚Äôll be able to do this without ever visiting the Stevens campus. A convenient online experience that combines synchronous live classes with self-paced asynchronous content accessible anywhere you can connect to the internet. StevensOnline students enjoy support from the Continuing and Professional Student Care Center from the time they apply until they graduate.
